journal-meta.journal-title: Journal of Reinforced Plastics and Composites

title-group.article-title: Hole quality evaluation of natural fiber composite using image analysis technique

article-meta.aff: 1Department of Mechanical Engineering, Anna University, Chennai, India
2Department of Mechanical Engineering, Rajalakshmi Engineering College, Chennai, India
3Department of Mechanical Engineering, Anna University, Chennai, India

author-notes.corresp: N Venkateshwaran, Department of Mechanical Engineering, Rajalakshmi Engineering College, Chennai, India. Email: venkatcad@yahoo.com

permissions.copyright-statement: © The Author(s) 2013 Reprints and permissions: sagepub.co.uk/journalsPermissions.nav

abstract.p: The natural fiber-reinforced composites are emerging as a possible replacement to glass fiber composite for low-cost applications. Of the various machining process, drilling is one of the most common machining processes used for the assemblage of various parts. During drilling process, composites undergo delamination phenomenon that reduces the structural reliability of the component. The present work focuses on the analysis of delamination behaviour as a function of drilling process parameters at the entrance and exit of the composite plates. In this work, drilling was carried out by varying the feed (0.1, 0.2, 0.3 mm/rev) and speed (500, 1000, 1500 and 2000 r/min), respectively. The drill bit used is made of high-speed steel of a diameter of 10 mm. The quality of the hole drilled was assessed using the machine vision technique, and the extent of delamination was carried out using the ultrasonic C-scan imaging method. The experimentally observed delamination factor was compared with ANOVA technique and found that the feed rate affect the delamination than speed. A correlation between the parameters of interest was carried out using multi-variable linear regression analysis technique.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p:
The failure in drilling a composite is classified as fiber breakout, delamination and fracture. These mechanical failures contribute 60% of all the parts rejection during final assembly of an automotive1 and they have been recognised as one of the limiting factors in the use of composite in the automotive industry. One of the basic disadvantages associated with drilling the composite is “DELAMINATION”. Typical defects after drilling include stress concentration, interlaminar crack propagation, micro-cracking, fibre breakage, debonding, fibre pullout, matrix cratering, thermal damage, delamination, etc. Of these, delamination is one of the major defects, which affect the performance of the holes.2 Damage during drilling an anisotropic material depends on:
The nature and the mechanical characteristics of the long fibres used in the laminae.
The stacking sequence and the mechanical characteristics in differently oriented ply interfaces (matrix), throughout the laminate thickness.
Tool configuration/geometry.
Operating environment.
Process variables.3

Mechanism of delamination at each stage of drilling using the acoustic emission technique was carried out and it was found that characterising the damages using signals has been a most difficult task and hence offline techniques are most suitable for the damage evaluation.4 Comparison between the model developed and experimental values on damages caused during drilling thin carbon/epoxy composite was carried out by Lachaud et al.5 The model developed exhibit the relation between thrust force and localized bending on last few plies of laminae.5 Hocheng and Tsao6 studied the effect of drill geometries on the thrust force of composite and analysed the failure using classical plate bending theory and linear elastic fracture mechanics approach. Khashaba7 experimentally analysed the influence of drilling and material variables on thrust force, torque and delamination of GFRP composites. The results revealed that the material constituent, thickness and machining time have significant effect on thrust force and torque during drilling the composite. Further, it is also observed that the delamination associated with push-out is more severe than that of peel-up mechanism. Tsao and Hocheng8 evaluated the effect of different drill bits (twist drill, candle stick drill and saw drill) on delamination of carbon fiber-reinforced plastic (CFRP) laminate. From the research work, a correlation between the feed rate, spindle speed and drill diameter with the induced delamination was derived for the CFRP laminate. Hocheng and Tsao9 reviewed the delamination-free drilling of composite material. Their study provided that proper feed rate could avoid the delamination due to thrust in drilling. Various non-traditional methods of drilling like, water jet machining, ultrasonic machining, laser machining and vibration machining studies were compared with the traditional machining. Comparative study shows that water jet machining drills holes fast and fine for medium- and large-size hole. By laser cutting, machining zones are affected by heat and hence proper control of it is required to get delamination free holes. The use of computerised tomography for the evaluation of delamination produced by drilling the carbon-epoxy composite as a feasible tool was analysed by Tsao and Hocheng.10 Mohan et al.11 used taguchi optimisation method to optimise cutting parameters in drilling of glass fibre-reinforced composite material. From the study, it is found that speed and drill size has more significant influence on cutting force than thickness and the feed rate. Palanikumar and Davim12 developed a mathematical model to predict the tool wear rate of glass fiber-reinforced composite. The model developed has successfully predicted the tool wear rate under different parameters of study. Tsao and Hocheng13 studied the effect of tool wear on delamination of carbon fiber-reinforced composite. The study revealed that the delamination is more liable to occur, as the critical thrust force is higher with increasing wear. Velayudham et al.14 analysed the dynamics of drilling of high-volume fraction glass fiber-reinforced composite. The study showed that at higher cutting speed and feed there a marginal variation in thrust and wear occurred. Abrao et al.15 reviewed the works on drilling of GFRP and CFRP composite with references to tool materials and geometry, machining parameters and their influence on the thrust force and torque. Davim et al.16 evaluated the delamination in CFRP laminates using digital image technique. It showed that the acquisition system used has allowed the collection and analysis of the damage produced after drilling composites. Karnik et al.17 analysed the delamination in CFRP during high-speed machining (HSM) using ANN Model with spindle speed, feed rate and point angle as the affecting parameters. The simulation results showed the effectiveness of the ANN models to analyze the effects of drilling process parameters on delamination factor. Tsao and Hocheng18 evaluated the thrust force and surface roughness in drilling of composite material using taguchi and neural network. The results indicate that the radial basis function network yields more effective results than multi-variable regression analysis. The study by Islam19 showed that laminate stacking influences the cutting performance on CFRP. Palanikumar20 used the grey technique analysis to optimise the cutting parameters of drilling GFRP. It showed that this technique converts the multiple performance characteristics into single performance characteristics and it simplifies the optimization procedure. Vijayan et al.21 used Genetic Algorithm technique to find the optimum cutting conditions for defect-free drilling. It showed that under optimum conditions, the peel-up delamination was lesser when compared to push-out delamination. Rubio et al.22 used the digital technique to analyse the damage level to access the delamination in HSM of GFRP composite. The result showed that the HSM ensures the low damage level in GFRP composite. Davim et al.23 analysed the effect of process parameters on delamination factor of carbon fibre-reinforced composite with the help of digital image analysis technique.

sec.title: Materials and methods
sec.p:
Banana fiber (Musaceae family), a type of bast fiber, is extracted from the bark of banana tree. Banana fibers were procured from local dealer. Epoxy LY556 of density 1.15–1.20 g/cm3 mixed with hardener HY951 of density 0.97–0.99 g/cm3 is used to prepare the composite plate with fibers oriented in random fashion of 15 mm length and 20-wt%. Mould used in this work is made of well-seasoned teak wood of 300 mm × 300 mm × 10 mm dimension with 8 beadings. The fabrication of the composite material was carried out through the hand lay-up technique. The top, bottom surfaces of the mould and the walls are coated with remover and allowed to dry. The functions of top and bottom plates are to cover, compress the fiber after the epoxy is applied and also to avoid the debris from entering into the composite parts during the curing time. The moulds are cleaned and dried before applying epoxy. The fibers were laid uniformly over the mould before applying any releasing agent or epoxy. After arranging the fibers uniformly, they were compressed for a few minutes in the mould. Then the compressed forms of fibers were removed from the mould. This was followed by applying the releasing agent on the mould, after which a coat of epoxy was applied. The compressed fiber was laid over the coat of epoxy, ensuring uniform distribution of fibers. The epoxy mixture is then poured over the fiber uniformly and compressed for a curing time of 24 h. After the curing process, laminate was cut to the required dimensions as shown in Figure 1. Figure 1.
Composite laminate of banana fiber/epoxy.

Drill tool made of 10 mm High Speed Steel (HSS) used in this work is as shown in Figure 2. The equipment used in this research work is CNC vertical machining center whose specifications are listed in Table 1 and shown in Figure 3. The diameters of the drilled hole are analysed using machine vision technique at TIFAC CORE center for machine vision at Rajalakshmi Engineering College, Chennai, India. The specification and details of equipment used are listed in Table 2 and the same is shown in Figure 4. Figure 2.
Drill bit of 10 mm HSS used.
Figure 3.

Figure 4.

In this current work, hole quality was assessed using C-scan imaging technique also. The C-scan provides a plan type view of the location and size of the test specimen. The plan image is parallel to the scan pattern of the transducer. C-scan presentations are produced with an automated data acquisition system such as computer-controlled immersion scanning system. The C-scan presentation provides an image of the features that reflect and scatter the sound within and on the surface of the test pieces. Equipment used in this research is shown in Figure 5 and the specifications are listed in Table 3. Further, equipment used is available at Centre for Non-Destructive Evaluation of Machine Design Section of IIT (Madras). In this work, drilling was carried out by varying the feed (0.1, 0.2, 0.3 mm/rev) and speed (500, 1000, 1500 and 2000 r/min), respectively, and the same is listed in Table 4. Figure 5.
Ultrasonic equipment used.

sec.title: Results and discussion
sec.p:
Delamination in the banana/epoxy composite was analysed by measuring the hole size after drilling by using the machine vision technique. The hole size at entry and exit of the tool was calculated from the pixel value. The details regarding the hole size and pixel value at entry and exit are given in Tables 5 and 6, respectively. From the above tables, the delamination factor was calculated, using equation (1). The average hole diameter was used to calculate the delamination factor and are shown in Tables 7 and 8 for entry and exit of the tool. (1)Fd=Dmax/D where Dmax is the maximum diameter of the damaged zone, and D is the diameter of the hole. Table 5.

Tables 7 and 8 show that delamination increases with an increase in the velocity and feed. The effect of the feed on the delamination factor at entry and exit is shown in Figures 6 and 7, respectively. At low speed and feed, the delamination is lower when compared with all other parameters used, i.e. on increasing the speed and feed, the delamination increases. In entry delamination, at 0.3 mm/rev of the feed irrespective of speed, except 2000 r/min, the delamination factor is almost the same. In the exit case, the delamination factor is the same at 0.2 mm/rev, except at high cutting speed. Similar kind of result was also observed by Palanikumar20 and Davim et al.24 Figure 6.
Effect of the feed on the delamination factor at entry.
Figure 7.
Effect of the feed on the delamination factor at exit.

sec.title: C-scan analysis
sec.p:
An ultrasonic C-scan, using sound energy at frequencies above 10 kHz, detects the defects of the composite specimen prepared. The tested specimens immersed in water were scanned at normal incidence in the pulse-echo mode, by means of a focused broadband transducer (3.2 mm diameter, 12 mm focal length), with a frequency of 5 MHz. The testing device consists of a 0.025 mm resolution scanning bridge. Based on the binary images, the drilling delamination factor is determined by the ratio of the maximum diameter (Dmax) of the delamination zone to the hole diameter (D). Figures 8 and 9 show the sample images obtained from the ultrasonic C-scan testing technique. Figure 8.
C-scan image of the composite at 4-mm depth.
Figure 9.
C-scan image of the composite at 8-mm depth.

sec.title: ANOVA analysis
sec.p: Further, the effect of parameters on the drilling of composites was analysed through ANOVA. The main aim of ANOVA is to apply a statistical method in order to identify the effect of the individual factors. The impact of each factor on the results can be determined very clearly, using the ANOVA technique. It also provides information about the percentage contribution of the individual parameters. It is observed that the p value for the parameter feed is less than 0.05(α), thus indicating that the feed significantly affects the machining performance.

Table 9 shows the results of the ANOVA analysis for the pushout type of delamination in the composite. The value of “P” in the ANOVA table indicates the percentage contribution by each parameter. The percentage contribution by feed is 51.73 and that of speed is 28.45 at entry delamination. Hence, from the p value, it is found that the feed has a more dominant effect on delamination than speed. Similarly, from Table 10, it is seen that the percentage contribution by feed and speed are 36.66 and 53.13, respectively. This also indicates that feed has a significant effect on exit delamination too. Table 9.
Result of ANOVA during entry delamination.

sec.title: Regression analysis
sec.p: In general, the multi-variable regression analysis is used to derive the relationship between the dependent and independent variables. To derive the mathematical relationship between the delamination Factor (FD) and the cutting parameters (speed and feed) in the drilling of the banana/epoxy composite, the multi-variable regression analysis was carried out to derive the following equations. Tables 10 and 11 show the results of the regression analysis carried out at entry and exit delamination. The relationship between the delamination factor and the cutting parameters can be written as: (2)FD-Entry=1.021+0.000479S+0.0886F

From Table 11, it is seen that the adjusted R2 value is 88.4%, i.e., equation (2) provides values which is 88.4% of accuracy. Similarly, the exit delamination equation can be written from the Table 12 as: (3)FD-Exit=1.029+0.000167S+0.0606F Table 11.

Tables 13 and 14 show the comparison of the experimental delamination factor (Fd) with the predicted delamination factor, using the regression model at entry and exit. It shows that the maximum error percentage between the experimental delamination factor and the regression model at entry and exit is 0.678 and 0.357, respectively. This shows that equations (2) and (3) correlate the delamination factor in the composite with the cutting parameters with a good degree of approximation. Table 13.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p:
From this study on hole quality analysis, the effect of delamination in composite during drilling of the banana/epoxy composite was analysed and the following points are drawn:
The delamination factor increases with both the cutting parameters (Speed and Feed), which means that the composite delamination increases with increasing the processing parameters of concern.
ANOVA analysis shows that out of the two parameters considered, feed affects the delamination more than speed with a significance of 51.73 at entry and 53.13 at exit, respectively.
The delamination factor predicted using the regression model has the maximum error of 0.678 at entry and 0.357 at exit when compared with the experimental analysis.
The extent in which the parameters affect the delamination is analysed using C-scan technique. It proved as one of the important source of analyzing the delamination in composite.

sec.title: Funding
sec.p: This research received no specific grant from any funding agency in the public, commercial, or not-for-profit sectors.
